title-group.article-title: Spontaneous emergence and drifting of sequential neural activity in recurrent networks

abstract.p: Repeating sequences of neural activity exist across diverse brain regions of different animals and are thought to underlie diverse computations. However, their emergence and evolution in the presence of on-going synaptic plasticity remain poorly understood. To gain mechanistic insights into this process, we modeled how biologically-inspired rules of activity-dependent synaptic plasticity in recurrent circuits interact to produce connectivity structures that support sequential neuronal activity. Even under unstructured inputs, our recurrent networks developed strong unidirectional connections, resulting in spontaneous repeating spiking sequences. During ongoing plasticity these sequences repeated despite turnover of individual synaptic connections, a process reminiscent of synaptic drift. The turnover process occurred over different timescales, with certain connectivity types and motif structures leading to sequences with different volatility. Structured inputs could reinforce or retrain the resulting connectivity structures underlying sequences, enabling stable but still flexible encoding of inputs. Our model unveils the interplay between synaptic plasticity and sequential activity in recurrent networks, providing insights into how brains implement reliable but flexible computations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Repeating sequences of neural activity are reported across many species and brain regions, including in the navigational, sensory, and motor areas of mammals, reptiles, and birds, and believed to underlie many computations. Perhaps the most striking example of repeating sequences is in the motor area of songbirds [1]. Zebrafinches repeat their courtship song thousands of times with a perfectly matching sequential representation in their brain. In the hippocampus of rats, sequences of spikes encode place trajectories as the animal moves, and they are replayed during rest [2, 3]. Repeating sequences of spikes are also common in the sensory cortices of rats, humans, mice, and turtles [4–7]. Yet, whether and how these sequences emerge and change over time to flexibly implement these computations remains poorly understood.

However, the reported sequences are hardly stereotyped. An increasing body of experimental evidence shows that representations in multiple brain areas are often subject to “drift” [8–12] where one neuronal pattern of activations is slowly replaced by another. In the hippocampus, after the mapping of space is established [13–15], after the animals have been trained in the same environment and place fields have formed, spontaneous changes in the encoding, a phenomenon known as “remapping”, reorganize the existing sequences [16, 17]. In the birdsong system, sequences are first learned and heavily modified by the juvenile bird as it develops its own version before the song crystallizes [18]. Even as an adult, the song can be modified under acute manipulations of their auditory system, indicative of the ongoing plasticity to which it is exposed [19, 20]. These sequences of spikes are not fixed ensembles as observed in partial out-of-order reproductions during sleep [21]. Even though the zebra finch is a specialist of one song, it still produces other non-courtship vocalizations in adulthood using the same motor areas [22–24]. Related species such as budgerigars, bengalese finches and canaries present more variable songs and even life-long learning, suggesting that the neuronal substrate underlying the sequences may be more plastic than typically assumed [25–27].

The specific processes driving these fast and slow changes in sequences of neural activations are unknown, but likely relate to activity-dependent synaptic plasticity due to sensory experience [28, 29] or developmental spontaneous activity prior to the onset of sensory experience [30, 31]. Indeed, a plethora of plasticity mechanisms have been studied, theoretically and experimentally, and are considered the main actors of organization of recurrent networks of neurons [32–37]. Experimental and theoretical evidence has put forward spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) as the underlying plasticity mechanism which describes synaptic change based on the order and timing of pre- and postsynaptic spikes [33, 34, 38]. Nonetheless, many forms of STDP have been described, which depend on pairs or triplets of spikes, operate at different timescales and have Hebbian or anti-Hebbian effects, depending on which order of the spikes induces potentiation or depression [33, 35, 39–41]. Moreover, these STDP rules depend on brain region, cell type, and the presence of different neuromodulators [42, 43]. These different forms of STDP can have different influences on recurrent network connectivity. For example, Hebbian forms of symmetric pair-based STDP, shifted asymmetric STDP, or rate-dependent triplet STDP has been shown to promote the formation of “neuronal assemblies” [40, 41, 44–46], groups of neurons sharing strong connections and exhibiting coordinated firing [44, 47]. In contrast, anti-symmetric Hebbian STDP has been shown to promote the formation of “synfire chains”, a form of idealized sequential structures [35]. What specific synaptic plasticity rules promote structures of directed connectivity characteristic of the repeatable, but still flexible sequential activity widely seen experimentally, is still unknown. Furthermore, if plasticity, structure and activity are interlocked in a recurrent loop where each one drives the next, one might assume that repeating neuronal patterns might be self-preserving and a fixed phenomenon. Previous theoretical work has suggested that sequences provide stable output and robustly encode memories despite ongoing plastic processes [48, 49]. However, if, as described above, neuronal representations are subject to constant change, driven through either internal dynamics or external stimuli, we lack an understanding of how this change affects the repeatability of sequences and their underlying structures.

How repeatable are sequences of neuronal activations that occur in an intrinsically plastic system such as cortex? Here, we asked how activity-dependent synaptic plasticity may naturally produce the connectivity structures underlying repeatable sequences, and how these very same plasticity mechanisms alter them. To mechanistically dissect this question, we built a recurrent, plastic, spiking network model that produced sequences that repeated but also evolved. Driven by unstructured activity, the network spontaneously developed connectivity structures that led to the appearance of spiking sequences. However, these same plastic processes also created volatile dynamics of synaptic turnover with different timescales depending on synapse type, strength and connectivity motifs. Exposing the network to structured inputs revealed that the same plasticity mechanisms under random dynamics could stabilize patterns over extended periods, remaining flexible to re-encode new inputs. Overall, our work addresses how the interaction between plasticity rules and mechanisms of sequential propagation lead to stability and adaptability in neural networks, which is crucial to understand neuronal representations and learning in dynamic environments.

sec.title: Synaptic strengths generated by plasticity produce repeating sequences
sec.p: Long-tailed distributions of synaptic strengths can be sufficient for generating reliable sequential neural activity [50]. Thus, we first focused on identifying plasticity rules that produced such distributions in random networks and verified that they produced sequential activity. We built a neural network with randomly connected excitatory (E) and inhibitory (I) adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire neurons [51] (Fig. 1A). We modeled spontaneous activity as uncorrelated Poisson inputs independently sampled for every neuron. E-to-E and I-to-E connections followed spike-timing-dependent plasticity rules (eSTDP and iSTDP respectively, Fig. 1A) [34, 38, 52] and were subject to weight normalization [53, 54]). In addition, excitatory neurons experienced intrinsic synaptic plasticity [55,56] which adjusted their firing thresholds to their firing rate, preventing any small fraction of the neurons from dominating the entire network.

Since intrinsic plasticity adjusted the firing thresholds, we studied synaptic strengths after scaling them by the distance between the post-synaptic neuron’s threshold and resting potentials. We refer to this value as effective weight (Weff = W/(Vth − V0)), which provides a good indicator of the likelihood that a presynaptic activation would trigger a postsynaptic spike (Fig. 1B). The steady state of the plastic network subjected to uncorrelated inputs resulted in an E-to-E effective weight distribution that was skewed, with a long tail well described by a lognormal distribution (Fig. 1C). We found that the rare strong connections in the tail of the distribution were distributed among the whole excitatory population, with most excitatory neurons having at least one such connection (Fig. 1D).

To test the generation of sequences, we randomly selected an excitatory neuron (source neuron) in the model network, forced it to produce spikes at regular intervals (Fig. 1E) and measured the response of all other neurons in the network. Plasticity was turned off only during this testing in our simulations. Each of the 1,000 source spikes defined a trial. We quantified the resulting firing rate modulation as the difference between each neuron’s firing rate after and before the source neuron spikes. We call “followers” those neurons that exhibited a significantly high firing rate modulation when compared to a null model with no injected spikes (Methods). Out of 155 tested source neurons in a model network, 135 (87.1%) of them had at least one excitatory follower (Fig. S1). The median number of excitatory followers (excluding 0) was 55, and source neurons could have more than 120 excitatory followers (Fig. S1A).

Source spikes caused the activation of followers in the same sequence across trials (Fig. 1E, S2, and S3, [7]). Followers could activate after the source spike with a delay up to 150 ms, much longer than the timescales of neuronal dynamics. Different subsets of all followers fired in every single trial (55% excitatory and 74% inhibitory followers per trial on average, S1B). We thus defined the responding probability of a follower as the ratio out of all trials in which it fired at least once within 300 ms from the source spike. Across all followers, the median delay and the jitter increased together, while both of them decreased with increasing responding probability (Fig. 1F, Fig. S4).

Surprisingly, although the model lacked E-to-I plasticity and thus could not produce strong connections onto inhibitory neurons, it did produce inhibitory followers (median: 33, 45.8% of source neurons) (Fig. S1). Compared to excitatory followers with the same responding probability or median delay, inhibitory followers had a larger jitter (Fig. 1F and S3). We found that the activation of inhibitory followers results in feedback inhibition onto the source neuron (Fig. S5), possibly explaining post-spike hyperpolarization observed experimentally [7].

In summary, plasticity in our network generated connectivity that promotes the appearance of sequences even under random inputs. Single spikes in most excitatory neurons reliably trigger sequences of spikes in the rest of the network that repeat from trial to trial.

sec.title: Strong excitatory connections resist turnover under uncorrelated inputs
sec.p: Although our model network converged to a steady state in terms of the distribution of effective weights, individual connections were still under the effects of ongoing plasticity (distribution and single example connections tracked in Fig. 2A). Since sequences in our networks are mainly driven by strong connections [50], these changes could limit the capacity of the network to produce repeatable sequences over long timescales.

We first defined the ratio of strong E-to-E connections to the number of all possible E-to-E connections (peeNe(Ne −1), Fig. 2B). Once the steady state was reached, our network could always produce sequences as a consequence of a stable number of strong connections distributed over the network independent of their exact identity. When we tracked small groups of E-to-E connections that lived in the tail of the distribution at a given time point (Weff > 2.5, Fig. S1D), we found that they had been weak in the past and would become weak again in the future (Fig. 2C). This group would then be replaced by a new group of connections preserving the tail of the distribution. Strong I-to-E connections followed the same dynamics (Fig. S6A). Indeed, under our uncorrelated inputs, the probability that a connection remained strong after a given period decayed exponentially (Fig. 2D, blue).

Is the decay of strong connections slow or fast compared to network dynamics? To establish a decay baseline, we simulated a baseline network, under the same plasticity rules, where all the neurons generated independent Poisson spikes with the same rate as our network simulations (Fig. 2D, gray). We found the decay of strong connections was much slower than this random baseline. This slowed decay is likely the product of the synaptic potentiation resulting from the anti-symmetric eSTDP rule combined with positive spiking correlations between pre and post synaptic units. Indeed, I-to-E connections, subject to symmetric iSTDP and negative correlations resulting from inhibition, showed decays very close to baseline (Fig. 2D, red).

Strong E-to-E connections were not just slower in decay when compared to I-to-E, but also when compared to weak E-to-E connections in the body of the distribution. We quantified the turnover of weak connections (Weff ∈ (0.5, 2.5]) as the ratio of connections that remained above their lower bound after some elapsed time. The ratio first decreased and then saturated (Fig. 2E and S6B), and could be described with an exponential function and a baseline, i.e., 1 − a [1 − exp(−t/τ)]. The time constant for weak connections (τ = 856 s) was of the same scale as our baseline and I-to-E fit (Fig. 2D, gray and red) and again much shorter than that of strong connections (Weff > 2.5; τ = 1, 605 s). Interestingly, I-to-E connections showed the opposite trend: strong connections decayed slightly faster (Weff > 2.5; τ = 599 s) than weak ones (Weff ∈ (0.5, 2.5]; τ = 781 s) (Fig. S6B).

In summary, under uncorrelated inputs and ongoing plasticity, our networks displayed stability at the global level of synaptic strength distributions, but volatility of individual connections. While all connections experienced turnover in their strength, the strongest E-to-E connections displayed slower decay than the rest of the network. These strong connections thus provide a backbone of sequential activity.

sec.title: Plasticity promotes connectivity motifs involved in sequential propagation
sec.p: While single strong connections are key to sequences of spikes in our networks, studies have shown that certain connectivity motifs are more likely to appear or to be activated in recurrent cortical networks [50, 57–60]. Hence, we next investigated how plasticity structures the connectivity motifs of our networks and their role in the propagation of sequential activity.

We focused on four 3-neuron motif types composed of strong E-to-E connections: linear chains, divergence motifs, convergence motifs and fan-in/out motifs (Weff > 2.5, Fig. 3A). Note that one more 3-neuron motif is possible: a cycle motif, where all three neurons are connected in a recurrent loop [59, 61]. However, due to the asymmetry of the eSTDP rule, the cycle motif was extremely unlikely in our network (similar to [61]), with an average of 0.08 motifs per network instance.

We defined the ratio of number of detected motifs divided by the total number of possible sites to form a motif (see Methods for each motif). When we tracked the ratio of each motif type, we observed a sudden increase in the ratio of strong motifs for all motif types, followed by a steady state (Fig. 3B). This increase mimicked that observed for single connections (Fig. 2B), but was not merely a consequence of it. When we estimated the ratio of motifs in a random network, given the same probability of strong unidirectional connections, we found that our steady-state networks over-represented “fan-in/out” motifs and under-represented all other motif types (Fig. 3C).

We hypothesized that the presence of convergence and divergence motifs was limited by the competition between multiple connections on a single neuron that results from weight normalization. Additionally, intrinsic plasticity, by imposing the same target firing rate on all neurons, also discourages the clustering of strong connections on single neurons required for these motifs. To verify this hypothesis, we disabled the presynaptic weight normalization and intrinsic plasticity on E neurons in new simulations. We found all of the motif ratios in these alternative models were above random levels (Fig. S7A), but the ratio of strong connections was lower (2.1 × 10−3 vs. 0.021). This alternative model contained a small number (4%) of neurons that receive from or give away to other neurons most of the strong connections. These “hub” neurons also fired much more frequently than average, exerting a large impact on the network dynamics (Fig. S7B, [62–64]). Only ~5% of the excitatory neurons (the hub neurons) had followers and their activation was very short lived (<20ms), closer to synchronous firing than to sequential propagation (Fig. S7C-D). We concluded that the plasticity rules that promote the homogeneous distribution of strong connections required for sequential activity simultaneously limit the presence of divergent and convergent motifs. If this argument were true, then fan-in/out motifs should also be limited by the plastic mechanisms described above. Removing any one of the three strong connections from a fan-in/out motif transforms it into one of the other three studied here. Given the turnover of single strong connections (Fig. 2B), it is thus surprising that fan-in/out motifs were so over-represented.

An alternative hypothesis for the over-representation of fan-in/out motifs is self-reinforcement. To test this, we explored the turnover rate of the fan-in/out motif relative to single strong connections. We thus established a baseline where we exchanged a random selection of strong connections with weak ones to achieve the same turnover rate of individual strong E-to-E connections as before (Fig. 2D). The decay time constant of the shuffled fan-in/out motifs was approximately 1/3 of the time constant of strong unidirectional connections under normal turnover (i.e., τmotif ′≃τee/3) (Fig. 2D). In contrast, fan-in/out motifs decayed more slowly than this baseline (Fig. 3D). Therefore, the slow decay of the fan-in/out motif could not be ascribed exclusively to the slow decay of single strong connections, but rather indicates the existence of higher-order self-reinforcing effects, likely driven through the effect of eSTDP. When we performed equivalent analysis for the other motif types, we observed faster-than-expected decays (Fig. S8), showing that these motifs are not only less common but also highly volatile.

We then evaluated if these motifs supported sequential propagation specifically. We considered only the E-to-E connections among the source neuron and its most reliable followers (responding probability ≥ 0.8). We calculated the relative percentage of each motif type (Fig. 3E, top pie chart), then normalized the motif percentages in the sequences by the motif percentages for the full network (Fig. 3E, bottom pie chart). We found that the fan-in/out motifs appeared even more frequently among followers than in the full network, where they are already over-represented (Fig. 3E, dots).

Taken together, our results show that plasticity rules produce specific structures of connectivity that support the reliable propagation of sequential activity. Fan-in/out motifs of strong connections self-reinforce, resulting in a slow decay of the motif and their over-representation across the entire network and among followers. Convergence and divergence motifs on the other hand are suppressed through heterosynaptic plasticity, which promotes an homogeneous distribution of strong connections within the network.

sec.title: Turnover of strong connections causes a turnover in sequence composition
sec.p: The decay of strong E-to-E connections and fan-in/out motifs, despite being slower than other network dynamics, can cause their disappearance and therefore the destruction of sequential structure. However, network statistics, such as the distribution of synaptic strengths, remain stable, suggesting that new sequences emerge. Indeed, sequences initiated by the same source neuron at different time points exhibited different follower compositions, where some remained, some were lost, and new ones appeared (Fig. 4A). We compared new and lost followers within 100 s intervals and averaged over 50 sequences (Fig. 4B). The net increase of the number of followers (new - lost) in a 100 s interval was −0.1 ± 30.6, indicating that the size of the sequences remained stable over time.

To evaluate the speed of follower turnover, we first pooled 2,931 followers from 50 randomly selected source neurons over 10 model networks trained with the same plasticity rules and parameters. The followers were detected at the steady state of the network (t = 8, 000 s). We then re-evaluated if these neurons continued to classify as followers at regular intervals within the steady state. We found that the ratio of initial followers that remain followers dropped exponentially (Fig. 4C).

The time constant of follower turnover was much shorter than that of strong connections (Fig. 2D). To characterize the differences in turnover rates among followers, we analyzed followers based on their responding probabilities and delays. We found that the ratio of remaining followers was the highest for followers with the highest responding probability and shortest delay (Fig. 4D, Fig. S9A). Considering that strong E-to-E connections are the main conduit of follower activation (Fig. 1, [50]), we calculated the length of the shortest path connecting each follower to its source using only strong E-to-E connections (which we call “synaptic jumps”). The length of this path negatively correlated with the follower’s responding probability and positively correlated with its median delay (Fig. S9B-C). Consistent with these correlations, the remaining ratio of of followers also decreased with an increasing number of synaptic jumps (Fig. 4E). In summary, followers synaptically closest to the source neuron respond most reliably and are the most robust to turnover.

We next asked how long followers last and whether their properties evolve with ongoing plasticity. We divided a period (2,000 s) after reaching steady state into small intervals (100 s) and detected new, lost and remaining followers. In each of these intervals, new followers had lower responding probabilities than those that remained from the previous interval, as well as longer delays, and more synaptic jumps from the source neuron. The distribution of the responding probability of lost followers in every interval overlapped with that of new followers (Fig. 4F), confirming that the overall number of followers in the network remained stable (Fig. 2A). When pooling new followers from all intervals (n = 7, 189), we observed a skewed distribution of lifetimes (Fig. 4G), with most neurons being classified as followers for a short period. Interestingly, a small proportion (7.3%) of new followers lasted over 1,000 s, much longer than the time constant of the overall decay of followers, τseq = 459 s (Fig. 4D), suggesting that the network may stabilize some new followers after they are recruited. The responding probability of followers followed a non-monotonic trajectory, first increasing and then decreasing with time, that was common to all followers, independent of their lifetime (Fig. 4H). Some followers displayed remarkably long lifetimes, remaining followers for as long as our simulations. These highly stable followers also showed peak responding probability.

In summary, as with synaptic connection distributions, our networks under uncorrelated inputs showed stable global properties and local fluctuations. Single sequences experienced the appearance of new followers and disappearance of old ones so that the overall extent of sequential activity in the network remained constant. While many followers experienced short lifetimes with low responding probabilities, others could be stabilized in the network, becoming long-lasting and highly responsive followers.

sec.title: Structured inputs lead to structured connectivity and stable turnover
sec.p: Our results so far have addressed the dynamics of network structure (Fig. 2, Fig. 3) and its effects on sequential activity (Fig. 4) when the network is subject to uncorrelated inputs. Even under this apparent “noise”, we observed features of stability for structures supporting sequential activity (Fig. 2D, Fig. 3D, Fig. 4H). Next we addressed whether structured inputs may affect these structures.

We modeled temporally coherent afferent inputs targeted to groups of neurons to complement our ongoing spontaneous activity. We first defined random groups of neurons (ensembles) in the excitatory population and introduced a structured input pattern with pairwise correlations that sequentially shifted from ensemble to ensemble every 100 s (Fig. 5A). After 10,000 s of simulation, we observed a stable long-tailed distribution of synaptic strengths (Fig. S10A-B). As a result of the structured input, however, strong E-to-E connections concentrated within single ensembles, with very low chance (9.1 × 10−4) of strong connections between different ensembles (Fig. 5B-C). Consequently, followers were most likely found within the same ensemble (Fig. 5D). Pooling from 126 source neurons, we detected 252 followers in the same ensemble as their source and 155 followers in any other of the remaining 11 ensembles. The percentage of same-ensemble followers (61.9%) was much higher than what would be expected if followers were distributed uniformly (9.1%). Furthermore, same-ensemble followers had significantly higher responding probability than different-ensemble followers (0.47 ± 0.40 vs. 0.25 ± 0.28) and shorter delays (15.7 ± 10.6 ms vs. 24.8 ± 10.8 ms).

Structured inputs not only concentrated strong connections but also made them more stable than those resulting from training under uncorrelated activity (Fig. 5E, blue and gray). Furthermore, while turnover of single strong connections did occur, those decayed strong connections were quickly compensated by new ones in the same ensemble, preserving the high density of strong connections within ensembles and resulting in very stable connectivity (Fig. 5E, pink).

We next asked if these stable structures could be learned by a network that had been previously trained with uncorrelated activity. We first trained a network with unstructured inputs until it reached steady state (t = 8, 000 s), and then switched to structured inputs (Fig. 5F). We found that the network connectivity adjusted so that strong connections that existed between ensembles disappeared and new strong connections emerged within ensembles. Correspondingly, the percentage of same-ensemble followers rose from 8.3% to 42.9%.

Finally, we asked if these stable structures limited the capacity of the network to adapt to a change in the inputs. We first trained a network with correlated inputs until it reached steady state, and then switched to a new, randomly generated, pattern (Fig. 5G). Note that, since patterns were random and all neurons belonged to some ensemble, the two patterns had a slight overlap. The network re-structured its connectivity to produce sequences corresponding to new ensemble pattern and reached a stable steady state. Correspondingly, the percentage of same-ensemble followers of pattern A dropped from 78.7% to 9.0%, while the percentage of same-ensemble followers of pattern B rose from 5.5% to 68.8%.

In summary, correlated inputs can shape the connectivity that leads to sequences into clusters and stabilize them in our plastic network. Strong connections concentrate between neurons with correlated activity, yielding reliable followers and slowing down turnover. Despite this enhanced stability, the network remains still flexible to accommodate changes in its inputs and produce distinctive sequences that represent them.

sec.title: Temporally structured inputs lead to sequentially organized followers
sec.p: Our network could produce turnover of sequences in response to unstructured activity and stable sequences in response to structured activation of ensembles of neurons. Next, we asked how the network responded to structured inputs that are themselves temporally structured.

We modeled temporally structured inputs as Poisson spikes received by ensembles of 100 excitatory neurons, one ensemble at a time. This time, however, the inputs were much shorter in duration (10 ms), comparable to the timescale of single neuron dynamics in our model, and shifted quickly from one ensemble to the next without temporal gaps between them (Fig. 6A). Ensembles were ordered temporally and their sequential activation repeated in a circular fashion throughout the simulation.

After 16,000 s of simulation, the network again reached a steady state with a long-tailed distribution of synaptic strengths (Fig. S10C-D). We found that strong connections emerged not only within ensembles (diagonal of the connectivity matrix), but also from one ensemble to the next in the stimulus sequence (sub-diagonal, Fig. 6C). These next-ensemble connections resulted in the extension of sequences over multiple ensembles (Fig. 6D).

Strong connections within the same ensemble and from one ensemble to the next were more stable than strong connections in a network trained with unstructured Poisson inputs (Fig. 6E, blue and gray). As in the case of static ensembles, any strong connection that turned over in a consecutive ensemble pair was quickly compensated by the appearance of a new strong connection in same the ensemble pair. The effective turnover rate therefore was very low, with a time constant longer than our simulations (Fig. 6E, pink). This highly stable connectivity resulted in highly responsive and stable followers: followers in the same ensemble as their source neuron or in the next ensemble had a significantly higher responding probability than any follower in the other 10 ensembles (0.64 ± 0.40 vs. 0.40 ± 0.36 for same-ensemble; 0.53 ± 0.39 vs. 0.40 ± 0.36 for next-ensemble), as well as shorter delays (10.5 ± 9.9 ms vs. 28.0 ± 13.4 ms for same-ensemble; 13.7 ± 8.3 ms vs. 28.0 ± 13.4 ms for next-ensemble), (Fig. 6F).

Finally, we tested if this temporal structure could flexibly reorganize networks with two types of pre-existing structure: that resulting from uncorrelated inputs (Fig. 6G), and that resulting from a different, random, temporally structured input (Fig. 6H). We first subjected a network to either initial pattern until it reached steady state and then applied a new temporally structured input pattern (Fig. 6A). In both cases, the network quickly reorganized its strong E-to-E connections to the ensemble structure described above (Fig. 6C), resulting in sequences that activated over multiple ensembles and reflected the ordering of the new inputs.

In summary, temporally structured inputs could shape stable sequences that reflect the temporal order of the inputs. The resulting strong connections had a very low turnover ratio, creating a stable backbone of propagation that sequentially linked multiple groups of neurons. Nonetheless, this stable configuration was also flexible enough to adapt to changes in the input patterns.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Here, we investigated how repeating sequences of spikes may arise and change under continuous plasticity. We built a spiking neural network composed of recurrently connected excitatory and inhibitory neurons with biologically-plausible synaptic plasticity rules (Fig. 1A). We found the network spontaneously reached lognormal weight distribution and structures of connectivity that made it prone to produce sequences even under the complete absence of structured stimuli (Fig. 1C-G). Although the statistics of these structures were stable, particular synaptic weights and sequences evolved due to the constant turnover of connections (Fig. 2, Fig. 4). Still, the timescales of turnover were longer for features of connectivity that supported sequences when compared to random connectivity (Fig. 2D-E, Fig. 3). This lower volatility could be further reduced when the network was subjected to external structured stimuli (Fig. 5E, Fig. 6E). Indeed, the network could sustain representations for long periods of time while at the same time remaining sufficiently flexible to adapt to changes in the stimulus (Fig. 5G, Fig. 6G).

sec.title: Plasticity rules that promote sequential activity
sec.p: Our results, with sequential activity emerging from a random network, lend support to STDP being the main actor in producing sequences of spikes, as long as it is combined with stabilizing mechanisms such as weight normalization and intrinsic plasticity [38, 53, 55]. Together, these rules give rise to stable long-tailed weight distributions of excitatory connections (Fig. 1C) that then drive sequential activity (Fig. 1E, [35, 50, 52]). This particular combination of plasticity rules avoids the presence of dominant excitatory neurons that concentrate all strong connections (i.e., hub neurons [62–64]). Instead, strong connections are spread across the network, enabling long sequences that could start almost everywhere (Fig. 1D). Beyond single sequences, we also studied connectivity structures and found over-representation of motifs that promote sequential activation (fan-in/out motifs), consistent with experimental evidence on the routing of neuronal activity [59].

Beyond excitation, our work also involved plasticity of I-to-E connections through a symmetric iSTDP rule, resulting in a balance of excitation and inhibition (Fig. 1A, [34]). In consequence, excitatory neurons that initiate sequences receive strong feedback inhibition after the onset of the sequence (Fig. S5), as observed experimentally [7]. This is the result of inhibitory neurons starting to fire after multiple excitatory neurons have been activated as the sequence extends. (Fig. 1F). By reducing the activation of excitatory neurons in the sequence and surrounding neurons, this form of negative feedback mechanism might limit the growth of excitatory connections and contributing to their eventual turnover [65].

The stability of these long-tailed distributions of excitatory connections neither depended on the presence of structured input, nor was it impaired by it. Our simulations with correlated and temporally-structured inputs did not affect the statistics of our excitatory weight distributions (Fig. S10). The presence of structured input instead resulted in additional structures within the connectivity matrix. Correlated inputs over long timescales produced groups of recurrently connected neurons similar to neuronal “assemblies” (Fig. 5C, [35, 40]). Fast inputs with temporal structure on the other hand, produced cross-assembly connections similar to “neuronal clocks” (Fig. 6C, [48]). In both cases, we observed sequential activity of reliable followers and a slow turnover of the connectivity that produces them, highlighting the robustness and flexibility of these plasticity rules.

Long-tailed distributions of synaptic efficacies as well as sequential activation of neurons are widely observed phenomena across multiple brain areas and species [57, 58, 60, 62, 65–67]. Theoretical studies with different degrees of biological realism have proposed links between these two elements [35, 50, 52, 68, 69]. Our results from random networks under random input contribute to this link and propose the role of specific plasticity rules to explain the widespread presence of both, long-tailed distributions and spiking sequences, in the brain.

sec.title: Turnover of representations?
sec.p: Spiking sequences have been proposed to be an intrinsic feature of the brain, rather than a reflection of sequential input [3]. The brain can use these structures during learning to anchor representations. Our work with random connectivity and random input producing sequences provides a mechanism for the emergence of this representational substrate. However, despite the robust statistics of our networks, we found a constant turnover of synaptic connections (Fig. 2) that resulted in a constant turnover of followers (Fig. 4) and thus the eventual alteration of any given sequence. If sequences are often observed in sensory, motor and navigational cortices, and are meant to bind representations, how might this turnover affect the encoding of external stimuli, actions or places?

An increasing body of experimental evidence suggests that representations in the brain might be subject to a slow “drift”, where patterns of neuronal activity correlate with task features in the short timescale, but the overall representations radically change in the long term [8]. Drift has been reported in multiple brain regions, such as mice posterior parietal cortex (PPC, [70]), mice visual cortex [10,11], the hippocampus of mice and rats [16, 71], mice olfactory cortex [72], as well as Drosophila mushroom body [73]. The sequences that we describe here present sudden drops of single followers but overall slow changes of the whole sequence (Fig. 4) and thus seem suitable candidates to underlie some of these drifting representations. Recent work in the hippocampus suggests that slow drift of place representation at the scale of population codes may be the reflection of sudden changes of place fields at the level of single neurons, which is very consistent with our modeling results [74].

To deal with how a downstream area might decode a drifting representation, theoretical studies propose plastic readouts that can adjust to the encoding as long as the timescale of the drift is slower than the timescale of the decoding [75, 76]. Our sequences present a drift of the neurons involved at multiple timescales: more remote followers drop out more quickly while closer followers are more stable (Fig. 4), resulting in a slow drift in the representation at the scale of the whole sequence. Furthermore, since most neurons in our networks could elicit a sequence, multiple sequences may run in parallel [50], which could extend even further the stability of the representations when considering the whole population. Our work with structured input strongly supports this possibility: when considering any strong connection among the followers within an ensemble, turnover timescales became longer than our simulations (Fig. 5E, Fig. 6E, pink).

Interestingly, in the mouse primary visual cortex, the representations corresponding to some simple and basic visual stimuli (e.g., gratings) are very stable, while the representations of more natural and complex visual stimuli are more unstable [11]. This form of complexity-dependent drift seems consistent with the different turnover dynamics we observe between early (stable) followers and late (unstable) followers (Fig. 4). Previous modeling work showed that contextual network activation determines the dynamic activation of later followers, suggesting a higher degree of selectivity of later than earlier followers [50]. Our results would thus be consistent with early neurons in the sequence representing simpler stimuli, possibly receiving direct thalamic inputs, while later neurons representing more complex stimuli. These later, complex, representations would be more amenable to drift because they rely on the activation (and stability) of multiple strong connections within the recurrent circuit (Fig. 4E). Since natural environments likely present a large variety of slightly different stimuli, later followers with very high stimulus selectivity may activate very rarely, and, consequently, may be more prone to turnover under our plasticity rules, resulting in a stronger drift in terms of representation. This view aligns well with prior theoretical frameworks of sparse coding, which aimed to explain why the large majority of neurons are mostly silent [77].

Although representations of sequential activity primarily rely on strong connections, weak connections may also be highly relevant for their plasticity-driven turnover. The high volatility of weak connections in our simulations (2E) suggests a quick mechanism for network computations: If weak connections are particularly susceptible to plastic changes due to the network dynamics, they may be ideally positioned to implement fast flexibility into the network. Indeed, weak connections are likely to play a role in implementing competition and cooperation across multiple sequences [50]. Under this view, reactivation of sequences under changing inputs will be first subject to the modulation of weak connectivity and may, on a longer timescale, result in the reorganization of the more stable backbone of strong connections.

Finally, although our model network may capture features of stimulus representational drift, it has a limited memory capacity. Indeed, while changing of input patterns can be seen as a feature of flexible adaptation to changing stimulus statistics (Fig. 5F-G, Fig. 6G-H), it can also be interpreted as a volatile memory issue, commonly known as “catastrophic forgetting” [78]. A possible avenue of future research to address this issue may lie on the suitable dynamics of learning of a readout layer, as described above [75, 76], or on the mixed presentation of patterns, similar to previous modeling work on hippocampal sequence replay [79].

sec.title: Neuronal model
sec.p: We used the adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire neuronal model (AdEx, [51]) for both excitatory and inhibitory neurons in the network. The membrane potential dynamics of the neurons were governed by the following equation: (1)CmdVdt=−gL(V−EL)−ge(V−Ee)−gi(V−Ei)+Ispike(V)−u+I(t)+ξ(t), where Cm is the membrane capacitance, gL is the leaky conductance, ge and gi are the conductances of the excitatory and inhibitory channels. EL, Ee and Ei are reversal potentials of the leaky, excitatory, and inhibitory channels, respectively. I(t) is the background current following a Gaussian distribution with the mean µwn and the standard deviation σwn. It is resampled for every interval τwn. ξ(t) is the Poisson input representing spontaneous activity or input from other parts of the brain not included in the model. We formulated this as a combination of Dirac’s delta functions of time with amplitude ξext (2)ξ(t)=ξext∑iδ(t−ti), and the time points {ti} are sampled from an exponential distribution with time constant τext. u is an adaptation term following the differential equation below: (3)τududt=−au(V−EL)+buδ(t−tspike)−u.

Ispike(V) is an additional exponential function of the membrane potential V to simulate the spiking process. It can be written as (4)Ispike(V)=gLΔTexp(V−VthΔT), where Vth is the firing threshold and ΔT is a slope parameter which controls the steepness of the membrane potential trace just before a spike. The spiking time points of one neuron are determined as the time steps when the membrane potential exceeds Vpeak. After a spike, the membrane potential is reset to Vreset.

The excitatory and inhibitory channels, ge and gi, are determined by the incoming synaptic weights from excitatory and inhibitory neurons, respectively. They can be formulated as (5)dgedt=−geτe+∑i,jwiδ(t−tij), (5)dgidt=−giτi+∑k,jwkδ(t−tkj), where the index i corresponds to presynaptic excitatory neurons and wi denotes the excitatory incoming synaptic weights from them, while the index k refers to presynaptic inhibitory neurons and their associated connections. The index j denotes the spike timings and tij represents the spike train of the presynaptic neuron i.

sec.title: Network model
sec.p: The model neural network consisted of 1,200 excitatory (E) and 240 inhibitory (I) AdEx neurons [51] with sparse connections between all neuron types (Fig. 1A, Table 2). Initial connectivity was random and homogeneous, with weak strengths unable to cause a postsynaptic spike with a single presynaptic one. E-to-E and I-to-E connections were plastic, while E-to-I and I-to-I connections were static. The model did not include structural plasticity [80], such that no new connections were created or eliminated even if some of them decreased to zero due to plasticity. The sum of incoming E-to-E synaptic weights for each post-synaptic neuron was kept constant at Tee. Similarly, the sum of all the incoming I-to-E, E-to-I, and I-to-I connections for one neuron, equals to Tie, Tei, and Tii, respectively. In this initial network, the maximal effective E-to-E weight was ~ 0.5, much lower than the maximum after plasticity (~ 10) and the estimated threshold to trigger a postsynaptic spike (~ 2.5). A synaptic delay of 1.5 ms was modeled for all connections.

sec.title: Plasticity model
sec.p: The plasticity mechanisms in our model included four different components: excitatory STDP for E-to-E connections, inhibitory STDP for I-to-E connections, synaptic normalization, and intrinsic plasticity for excitatory neurons (Fig. 1A).

sec.title: 1. Excitatory STDP (eSTDP)
sec.p: The change of the synaptic weight of an E-to-E connection was determined as (7)Δwee={A+exp(−Δtτ+), Δt>0−A−exp(Δtτ−), Δt<0 for a pair of pre- and postsynaptic spikes separated by a temporal difference of Δt = tpost − tpre.

sec.title: 2. Inhibitory STDP (iSTDP)
sec.p: The change of the synaptic weight of an I-to-E connection was determined as (8)Δwie=Aiexp(−|Δt|τi) for a pair of pre- and postsynaptic spikes separated by a temporal difference between of Δt = tpost − tpre. Additionally, whenever there was a presynaptic spike, a weight change was applied: (9)Δwie=−ALTD

sec.title: 3. Weight normalization
sec.p: Pre- and postsynaptic weight normalizations were applied to both E-to-E and I-to-E connections. Post-synaptic normalization for E-to-E connections ensured that the sum of incoming excitatory synaptic weights for each postsynaptic excitatory neuron remained constant at Tee, using the updating rule below: (10)wjiee→TeeΣjwjiee.
Presynaptic normalization kept the sum of outgoing synaptic weights from excitatory neuron i at Siee, using the updating rule (11)wjiee→SieeΣiwjiee.

Similarly, for I-to-E connections, the sum of incoming inhibitory synaptic weights for each postsynaptic excitatory neuron was kept at T ie, while the sum of outgoing synaptic weights from inhibitory neuron i remained constant at Siie, using the rule (12)wjiie→TieΣjwjiie and (13)wjiie→SiieΣiwjiie.

sec.title: 4. Intrinsic plasticity for excitatory neurons
sec.p: All E neurons were subject to intrinsic plasticity, adjusting their firing thresholds to match a universal target firing rate for all neurons. If an E neuron fired more than the target rate, its firing threshold would increase to reduce the firing rate back to the target, and vice versa, as follows: (14)dVth,idt=ηIP(δ(t−tspikei)−rt) where Vth,i is the firing threshold of neuron i, tspikei is the spike time of neuron i. rt is the target firing rate and ηIP is the rate of intrinsic plasticity.

Due to the dynamic firing threshold of excitatory neurons and in order to quantify the real impact of synapses, we defined the “effective weight” Weff, which is the synaptic weight W divided by the distance from the resting potential V0 to the firing threshold Vth, i.e., (15)Weff =WVth−V0.
Here the resting potential is defined as the membrane potential when only the background inputs I(t) presents.

sec.title: Sequence extraction
sec.p: To start a sequence, we first shut down all the plasticity mechanisms operating on the network, and then we forced a neuron to spike. This forced neuron is called the “source neuron” of the sequence. The frequency of the Poisson input ξ(t) was reduced (τext = 4 ms) to compensate for the forced spike.

We ran a testing paradigm that lasted 43 seconds, with the first 3 s for the network to obtain stable activity. Then the first triggered spike occurred at t = 3.1 s. After that, a spike was triggered in the same source neuron for every 400 ms, resulting in 100 trials of the sequence. In each trial, We calculated for every neuron the “firing rate before stimulation” r1 as the firing rate in the 100 ms window just before the triggered spike, and the “firing rate after stimulation” r2 as the firing rate in the 300 ms window just after the triggered spike. We repeated this paradigm for 10 times and generated M = 1, 000 pairs of r1 and r2.

Meanwhile, we used ⟨r1⟩ and ⟨r2⟩ (averaged over all neurons and the M = 1, 000 trials) that we obtained above to build a null model with only one neuron and M′ = 10, 000 spike triggering. This neuron fired with Poisson statistics. Consistent with the paradigm above, in every 100 ms window before the spike triggering, the neuron fired at the firing rate ⟨r1⟩. In every 300 ms window after the spike triggering, the neuron fired at the firing rate ⟨r2⟩. This allowed us to have a null distribution of r1 and r2 with M′ = 10, 000 samples.

We defined the “firing rate modulation” (Δr) as the difference between r2 and r1, i.e., Δr = r2 − r1. Every pair of r1 and r2 could lead to one observation of Δr. To reduce noise, we divided the M = 1, 000 observations of Δr in the simulation and M′ = 10, 000 observations of Δr in the null model into 10 equal parts. In each part, we calculated the null model’s 95th percentile of Δr. For one specific neuron, only if its average Δr was higher than the 95th percentile of the null model in all the 10 parts could it be identified as a follower.

To calculate the responding probability, delay, and jitter(Fig. S3C-D), for every identified follower, in each of the M = 1, 000 trials of spike triggering, we searched for its first spike after the externally triggered spike. If no spike was detected within a 300 ms window after the spike triggering, we considered the follower unresponsive to the source neuron for that trial. If a spike was found, the elapsed time from the triggered spike was recorded as the delay. If a follower responded to the source neuron in M* out of the M = 1, 000 trials, its responding probability was then M*/M (Fig. 1E). A total of M* delays were recorded, with the median calculated as the median delay, and the standard deviation defined as the jitter.

After extracting the sequences generated from all excitatory neurons, we estimated the minimal effective weight required to trigger a follower. The threshold was estimated to be 2.5 nS/mV (Fig. S1C) and determined as the criterion to classify strong connections.

sec.title: Decay of connections
sec.p: When calculating the decay rate of connections at a given time interval, we retrospectively took multiple snapshots of the network (up to 11) starting from the end of the simulation, within the period when the network was in a steady state, with the specified time interval between each two snapshots. Then we calculated the ratio of remaining connections from one snapshot to the next and averaged these ratios across all snapshots, resulting in one data point corresponding to one instantiation of the network (Fig. 2D). For example, for a 2,000 s interval, we took snapshots at 16,000 s, 14,000 s, 12,000 s, 10,000 s, and 8,000 s, assuming the network reached the steady state after t = 8, 000 s. For a 100 s interval, snapshots were taken at 16,000 s, 15,900 s, …, 15,100 s, 15,000 s, covering the last ten 100 s intervals in the 16,000 s simulation. The decay of motifs were calculated following the same procedure.

The turnover time constant τ of connections or motifs was fitted using an exponential function: (16)r=a∗exp(−t/τ)+1−a, where r is the remaining ratio and t is the time interval. If there was no baseline in the exponential function, we fixed a = 1 in the fitting.

sec.title: Motif analysis
sec.p: The ratio of motif was calculated as the number of motifs found in the network (N) divided by the total number of all possible sites where a motif can emerge (N0). The numbers of sites were different for the multiple motif types we were investigating and were dependent on the number of neurons and the connection probability pee.
For the linear chains, (17)N0=P3Nepee2=pee2Ne(Ne−1)(Ne−2) where P is the permutation number.
For the convergence and divergence motif, (18)N0′=Ne(Ne−12)pee2=12pee2Ne(Ne−1)(Ne−2).
For the fan-in/out motif, (19)N0′′=NeP2Ne−1pee3=pee3Ne(Ne−1)(Ne−2).

Given a specific ratio of strong connection p0, we could calculate the ratio of motif in a random network, which was compared to the ratio of motif in our simulation (Fig. 3C). For the linear chains, the random ratio was (20)1N0(p0pee)2(1−p0pee)4Ne(Ne−1)(Ne−2)=p02(1−p0pee)4.
Similarly, for the convergence and divergence motif, the ratio was (21)1N0′(p0pee)2(1−p0pee)4Ne(Ne−1)(Ne−2)/2=p02(1−p0pee)4.
For the fan-in/out motif, the ratio was (22)1N0′′(p0pee)3(1−p0pee)3Ne(Ne−1)(Ne−2)=p03(1−p0pee)3.

sec.title: Follower turnover
sec.p: When analyzing follower turnover based on responding probabilities, delays, and synaptic jumps (Fig. 4D, 4E, and S9A), we selected an interval of 1000 s and took 9 snapshots of the network from t = 8, 000 s to t = 16, 000 s, generating 8 intervals to calculate the remaining ratio of followers. Taking Fig. 4D as an example, we selected 50 sequences and went over these 8 intervals, calculating the remaining ratio of the followers with given responding probability. This yielded 400 ratios, which were averaged using the number of followers in each snapshot as weights.

sec.title: Correlated and temporally shifting inputs
sec.p: Different parameters of the neuronal model were used when modeling these inputs (Fig. 5 and 6). Their values are listed below.

sec.title: Entropy and rank correlation of the sequence
sec.p: Following the same calculation as in [7], the entropy of a sequence was defined as (23)Hk=−∑iPiklogPik where Pik is the probability for follower i to be the kth to fire in the sequence. In a totally random sequence with n followers, Pik = 1/n for all the followers and the entropy for any k equals to (24)H0=−n∗1nlog1n=logn, allowing us to define the normalized entropy as Hk/H0. We took the n = 135 sequences in Fig. S1, calculated their normalized entropy, and then created 10 shuffled sequences for each of them (1350 in total) as a null model (Fig. S3A).

To calculate the rank correlation of sequences (Fig. S3B), we first defined an order matrix for every trial in which a spike was triggered. Specifically, for trial k, the order matrix Ok(i, j) was defined as (25)Ok(i,j)={1, followerifiredpriortofollowerj−1, followerjfiredpriortofolloweri0, oneoffolloweriandfollowerjdidn'tfire0, thedifferenceoftheirfiringtimewassmallerthan2ms
Then we defined (26)Sk,l(i)=〈Ok(i,j)Ol(i,j)〉j≠i.

As a result, a positive Sk,l(i) means the firing orders of follower i relative to other followers in trial k and trial l were similar. A negative Sk,l(i) means the firing orders were reversed. Then we could calculate the rank correlation for neuron i as (27)r(i)=〈Sk,l(i)〉k,l.

sec.title: Hub neurons
sec.p: In the network that generated hub neurons (Fig. S7), we removed presynaptic normalization and intrinsic plasticity. We also used some different parameters listed below.
